executive_summary: Colocation has experienced impressive growth over the past five years as companies shifted operations online during the pandemic. An intermediate step between internal server hosting and leasing space from a cloud provider, colocation services offer a middle ground. Operators of colocation services build a space conducive to computing, with massive electrical infrastructure, cooling capacity and high security. Still, clients will fill the racks they rent every year with their own servers, dramatically increasing hardware deployment speed and data security. This business model is most attractive to moderately sized businesses located within physical proximity of the colocation center to enable moderate oversight of the hardware. As a result, revenue will increase at a CAGR of 6.7% over the five years to 2023, reaching $55.4 billion, including growth of 6.9% in that year.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Colocation centers flourish during the COVID uncertainty
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During the COVID-19 pandemic, colocation centers experienced a surge in popularity as businesses sought out reliable computing solutions to address changing needs. Many enterprises chose to take advantage of colocation centers' ability to scale up resources rapidly by adding additional servers quickly and easily. The high level of security and monitoring offered by these facilities established them as an attractive option for organizations more concerned than ever with data safety and integrity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: An explosion in servers strains colocation infrastructure
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As computer hardware gets more powerful, the physical resources of colocation centers are becoming increasingly strained to keep up with demand. This has led some organizations to seek out alternative cloud hosting solutions as colocation facilities charge high prices to filter out only the most interested buyers. Furthermore, some data storage providers offer hybrid solutions that combine virtual and dedicated server environments depending on the customer's specific requirements, eliminating the need for colocation facilities entirely.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising electricity and water costs spike revenue, but lower profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Colocation center profit has spiked since the 2020 pandemic, not just because of increased digital technology usage, but also following the high price of combustible fuels and electricity. While an increasing number of colocation centers already run on 100.0% renewable energy, those which use fueled backup or grid sources of electricity have had to increase prices despite negotiating directly with utilities. For colocation centers in arid regions, renewable water supplies have also dried up; some locations will move to more expensive direct air cooling systems in the years ahead or find other exotic cooling solutions.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Protecting access to colocation centers' invaluable data becomes a priority
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: With any computing system, physical access to the hardware enables a nearly limitless number of basic yet effective cyberattacks, extracting valuable data from companies located many miles away. Colocation servers have doubled down on protecting their clients' hardware. Biometric recognition is relatively popular for limiting physical access to the building, while physical monitoring systems automatically alert clients to access of their server cages. Some colocation centers use a new model to secure data called edge computing. By combining a relatively secure data center network and processing sensitive information at each, colocation centers and their clients can reduce the impact of a physical intrusion.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CONTINUED GROWTH OF DIGITAL TECHNOLOGY BENEFITS COLOCATION SERVERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Revenue is set to grow due to increased demand from data processing and hosting services, the number of businesses and percentage of business services conducted online. Operators of colocation centers are set to raise costs to maintain profit, while long-term contracts and the riskiness of transporting technology will prevent customers from leaving. The number of businesses in the US needing significant digital technology will increase consistently in future years, but much of this demand will be absorbed by large cloud service providers that run their own data centers separate from this industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COLOCATION LOCATES INTERNATIONALLY TO MEET RISING DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite continued growth in United States colocation markets, larger opportunities are arising in Asia and Africa, where more people are using the internet for everyday tasks. The business model for these international centers is far different from their United States counterparts: labor and land are much less expensive, but the ever-important reliability is also far harder to achieve.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Cloud and Local Compute Will Squeeze Colocation Centers in the Middle
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Megalithic server farms run by technology companies will dominate the market for minor computing projects even more than they currently do, pushing colocation centers out of the single-server space. Simultaneously, server hardware is becoming far more accessible, and companies wanting to run their own datacenter can relatively easily set up a powerful network in the office closet. Colocation centers will have to navigate the shrinking middle ground by increasing convenience and leveraging their scale.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Colocation Centers Will Lead Third-Party AI Application Hosting
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Large language models and future artificial intelligence developments are likely to create extraordinary economic value and many new enterprises wishing to train AI systems. While running an AI for client-facing servers is compute-intensive enough, training one can take months of hard computing work which the major cloud providers will lend, if at a pretty penny. As fine-tuned and fully custom AI language models become normalized, colocation centers will be able to leverage their per-unit price advantage for many moderate-sized AI businesses, pulling them away from the major cloud providers.

industry_definition: Operators own and operate data centers that primarily lease equipment space to customers. Companies in the industry also offer auxiliary services including power management, security and network neutrality. Customers generally use industry services as off-site data storage to back up their data or to enable them to focus on other parts of their business without paying for these operations.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Price of electric power
threats: Price of computers and peripheral equipment

key_trends: Colocation centers offer a key middle ground, settled between the abstraction of cloud providers and the financial inefficiency of in-house data centers. Operators provide the compute-conducive space, but clients rent space for their own hardware.

COVID-19 pushed colocation centers to new heights, as companies scrambled to digitize their business models. But high personnel costs and advancing threats from the cloud have lowered colocation center revenue significantly.
Green energy investments are at the front of colocation operators' minds, as states and countries implement regulations for datacenter Energy Use
But the large, flat roofs of datacenters are frequently optimal for on-site solar or wind installations.

Even the pandemic failed to damage the consistent increasing revenue of most colocation centers. However, the industry is more susceptible to market downturns than ever before with a wider array of clients.
Colocation centers offer an enormous variety of rack space, but larger clients are taking greater advantage. Frequently, a colocation building will house the servers of only a few large businesses.

Businesses of all types are investing in colocation space, with computation, storage, backup and rendering all represented in the same building. However, technology companies are most likely to realize the benefits of colocation instead of simply leasing space from a primary cloud provider.

Colocation center operators choose to locate just outside of urban areas, gaining both space availability and proximity to potential business clients. A location is far more likely to make a sale if the client can oversee the server upkeep directly, making location choice key.

The Southwest region is rising as a colocation hub, with many high-tech companies following chip manufacturers to set up in the region. Getting water for server cooling is more challenging in this region, and operators frequently turn to expensive, exotic cooling systems that use less water.

Most colocation centers target clients of similar sizes, with only the largest going for multinational technology companies as clients. Most colocation operators service local clients that have a few regional locations and no good way to expand data processing.
Colocation center contracts are almost always multiple years long, giving clients little room to switch providers and operators little room to raise prices.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Technology and software-based companies are the primary market for colocation services, requiring high server capacity and bandwidth to process large data sets. Over the past years, the demand for these services has increased substantially due to the rise of always-online embedded devices.

Social media companies have seen rapid growth in usage due to people being able to access their profiles through mobile devices. Social media platforms of all types have increased their demand for colocation services to store larger amounts of consumer data and run search or matchmaking algorithms.

Data industries require large amounts of server space in addition to sustainable energy costs to handle excess capacity from downstream markets. With growing internet usage, many businesses have begun turning toward colocation service providers for efficient support infrastructure and secure storage options.

Communication carriers are often looking for colocation facilities due to their ability to handle large swaths of data required for phone calls and other internet-related demands. The locations of colocation services near internet exchange points makes them ideal for ultra-low latency for these markets.

The finance sector has been using colocation services for years to get closer to financial markets and transfer financial transactions securely. In recent years, use has grown further thanks in part to peer-to-peer direct transactions and same-day transfers using the FedNow system.

products_and_services.product_description: Customers looking to purchase a single server from a colocation center are frequently mid-sized businesses that are just starting out and need access to quick, reliable computing.

Larger businesses may opt for buying an entire rack's worth of servers from a colocation center. This can provide them with the flexibility to grow their computing needs as they expand while also saving costs due to discounts given at bulk purchases.

Individual users who may prefer buying their own dedicated device for better control over their data and applications will appreciate that colocation racks provide an easy way to have secure, off-site processing and storage in the event of a disaster.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As the percentage of services conducted online increases, companies need more room for their servers and call on colocation operators to provide this space and power. Conversely, if the percentage of online sales falls, companies will not likely need more server capacity in new regions of the country. The percentage of services conducted online is expected to rise in 2023.

An increase in the number of businesses expands demand for colocation facilities. Although large companies may have their infrastructure and a team of IT professionals, smaller companies that can't afford these costs often turn to colocation facilities or cloud providers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Price of Computers and Peripheral Equipment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: When the price of computers and peripheral equipment falls, it becomes less costly for companies to store servers at colocation services. Simultaneously, cloud providers which buy their own servers can leverage their massive scale to earn greater profit during higher technology prices while colocation centers can't. The price of computers and peripheral equipment is anticipated to fall in 2023 after the chip shortage concludes, but remain higher than years past, posing a potential threat to the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Private Investment in Computers and Software
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As companies invest more in computers and software, they're likely to require greater server capacity and more services from the industry.

Colocation centers operate at internet exchange points specifically designed to minimize connection time to clients. When internet traffic volume rises, businesses gain more value from being near the internet core than running their own data centers closer to the edge. In 2023, the quantity of global internet traffic is anticipated to increase, like every other year since the foundation of the internet.

Colocation facilities help customers reduce their energy bills. Many colocation operators have energy-efficient facilities, and since they call for a large amount of power, they can negotiate a discounted price from the utility provider; these reduced costs are then passed on to customers. Therefore, when the price of electric power increases, demand for colocation facilities also rises.

business_locations.location_description: Colocation centers in the Western United States tend to be favored due to the area's robust power grid and major cities. This region is also home to some of the largest technology companies in the world in the Silicon Valley sub-region, allowing colocation centers to tap into their resources and clientele. But California's sustainability laws are among the strictest in the nation, so colocation operators in this region have led efforts to implement green power and cooling for their servers.

The Mid-Atlantic region of America is known for being highly populated and having great access to a majority of the country's massive businesses. The physical proximity of Mid-Atlantic cities also reduces latency to reach a colocation-located server over the internet, making these providers optimal for ping-sensitive tasks such as internet gaming and remote desktop.
The Southwest region of America can be an attractive location for colocation centers due to its wide open spaces and plenty of available land for datacenter construction.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Colocation Facilities industry experiences a light level of government regulation.
Governments are now requiring large-scale energy reductions from server farms, which have resulted in increased operational costs and an increased complexity to manage these systems.
